 Gravity doesn't just attract massive objects, it bends spacetime. All particles, massive and massless travel in spacetime therefore any particle moving in spacetime is subject to its laws. This is why and how a massless particle can be bent by gravitation.
 
 Gravitational acceleration and inertial acceleration (like a rocket) are indistingushable form each other. This gives a clue to the nature of spacetime. The energy a particle possesses directly effects how it behaves in spacetime. So, a particle in a heavy gravitational well will experience a slowing of time relative to a particle farther away from a gravitational well. Identically a particle with high kinetic energy (velocity) will experience a slowing of time relative to a particle at a lower velocity. This difference in energy and time diation depends on the acceleration or energy change of a particle. There is something fundamental about the energy states of a particle and its experience of time relative to the external universe.

 Yes, imagine a person falling into a blackhole. As he gets closer to the event horizon his time slows down relative to an observer far away from the blackhole. In fact any signals he sends out gets redshifted as if he is accelerating away from the observer outside. As he approaches the event horizon his time slows down further relative to the outside observer, as he reaches the event horizen it actually looks like to the outside observer that the guy is frozen in time, however for the guy falling in he observes himself ripped apart in a nanosecond.

 I think you're a little confused on how frames of reference work. This isn't relativity, it's just basic mechanics. Whenever you talk about motion, or lack thereof, it always has to be relative to a given frame of reference. For example, if I'm walking towards the front of a moving train then I'm going 3 mph relative to the frame that's set in the train, but 63 mph relative to a frame set in the ground. You can define anything you like as a frame of reference, it all depends on what makes sense based on what you're trying to measure.
 
 The reason people sometimes have a problem getting this at first is that we have this great frame of reference all set for us, the earth. To all casual observations it really seems stationary, and so we get this "common sense" feeling that such a thing as a stationary, absolute frame of reference exists. Of course in this case common sense is wrong, since the earth is spinning around it's axis, and going around the sun, and all that other stuff. 
 
 So the point is that it makes no sense to just say that a point is stationary, you have to say it's stationary relative to some other point. Likewise you can't just say that something has a certain speed, you have to say that it has that speed in a given frame of reference.
the cosmological frame is the observable universe. so relative to everything that exists we are traveling at 600km/s. does that not make sense?

 It makes little difference if you are talking spacetime. Everything is relative. When you are closer to a mass your time slows relative to an observer farther away. Likewise, when you accelerate to increase your velocity relative to any other inertial frame your time slows down relative to that other inertial frame. All motion and spacetime is relative, you can't get around it.

the cosmological frame is the observable universe. so relative to everything that exists we are traveling at 600km/s. does that not make sense?

 
 Nope, not really. Everything we can see out there is moving relative to everything else. We can take any point we like and define everything else's motion relative to that point, but there is no single point in the universe which can be said to be stationary in any sort of absolute sense. 
 
 To use your example, we may be moving 600 km/s relative to our neighboring galaxy, but our galactic cluster is moving (i'm making numbers up here ) 10,000 km/s relative to our nieghboring cluster, and our super cluster (cluster of clusters) is moving even faster than that relative to some other super cluster. All motion is relative to some frame, and any frame will do. They are all equally valid.

 An interesting idea, but still not quite right.
 
 Let's simplify the universe a bit. Let's say that all that exists is you and me. We're both travelling in straight lines which are at right angles and would never intersect. From one point of view you could say that I was moving to the right on the X axis, and you were moving up from the point x=2, y=2. An equally good way of framing it would be to say you're moving straight up the Z axis, and I'm moving along the line y = -2. From my point of view (that is, relative to me) I'm holding still and you're moving up and to the left. For you, I'm moving down and to the right, while you're stationary. All of these are equally valid frames, there's no way to average them out and come up with an absolute one.

Nope, not really. Everything we can see out there is moving relative to everything else. We can take any point we like and define everything else's motion relative to that point, but there is no single point in the universe which can be said to be stationary in any sort of absolute sense. 
 
 To use your example, we may be moving 600 km/s relative to our neighboring galaxy, but our galactic cluster is moving (i'm making numbers up here ) 10,000 km/s relative to our nieghboring cluster, and our super cluster (cluster of clusters) is moving even faster than that relative to some other super cluster. All motion is relative to some frame, and any frame will do. They are all equally valid.

 Think of two objects in space. When object A accelerates relative to the object B, object A's spacetime slows down relative to the unaccelerated object. Thus when the accelerated object A slows back down to its inital velociy relative to object B less time has passed. So one cannot say there is a universal inertial frame other than that frame you carry with relative to every other particle individually in the universe. Massive objects also bend spacetime around themselves so that any observer has a different time dialation relative to the position of every other object.

Our cosmological frame contains our neighbouring galaxys wich is the local supercluster wich is dominated by the virgo cluster of galixies. This is being drawn towards the even more massive Hydra Centaurus supercluster and both are being drawn towards a vast concentration of galixies known as "the great attractor".

And it would be easy to tell if we're going to hit or not. All I have to do is look right at you. If I have to turn to keep looking at you, we'll miss. If I don't have to turn, we'll hit.
 
 
 

 If we were moving awayfrom each other at 2 m/s and then we referenced our movement from a point that was moving awayfrom each of us at the same velocity of 10 m/s, then relitave to the reference point we would be moving awayfrom it at 11 m/s each, but still only 2m/s awayfrom each other.

 I'm afraid that doesn't actually make sense. You can't just say "moving awayfrom each other at 2 m/s". You must reference the movement to some reference point to start with. Am I stationary, and you're moving at 2 m/s, or the other way around? Is there a point between the two of us that I'm moving away from at 1.5 m/s, and you're moving away at .5 m/s? Or are you moving towards the point at .5 m/s, while I move away from it at 2.5 m/s? These will all look exactly the same. This is an important point. In each of these cases the distance between us is increasing by 2 m/s, but our velocities vary depending on what reference point you use.

 You're just taking the center of mass between two objects, or rather the center of motion. If you try to take the observable universe as your ultimate reference point you run into a problem. The observable universe is isotrophic as far as we can tell. So no matter where you are it looks pretty much the same on the large scale, and the Big Bang had no center because the big bang created spacetime. All of spacetime was compressed together, but not centered anywhere. Therefore any center of motion calculation involving the universe will ultimately bring your zero point to your own location. So each observer has their unique zero point.

Also, what is entropy

 You're jumping all over here, aren't you? Entropy is a measure of the molecular disorder of a system. An interesting entropic tidbit: the entropy of an isolated system never decreases. So, if you want to, say, cool down an area, like the inside of your fridge, the only way to do that is to increase the entropy somewhere else by at least as much.

The dimensions of the universe are, as far as we understand it, inherent to the universe, hence it makes no sense to talk in physical terms about an area into which the universe expanded, especially as there is no before the universe either as time is part of the universe. As for reality that is not contained within the universe, could be almost anything. Personally I believe God is there, for a start. It is possible that there are dimensions outside the universe, but it really is a metaphysical, rather than a physical debate. It has been hypothecated that God is a higher dimensional being, and his apparent omniscience is the equivalent of us playing a game on a 2D map, with the addition of being able to see time as one of the dimensions.

 Let's be precise. You want to find the center of mass of the universe and use that as your reference point for defining other velocities? Is that it?

It's worth remembering that you can't find the centre of mass of something with no centre. An infinite universe cannot have a centre of mass, unless every point is the centre of mass, as in an infinite, isotropic, homogenous universe, such as ours appears to be, there is the same amount of mass in every direction.

 The center of the ball would not be the center of the mass of the ball.

 Right, now I remember. :)
 
 Ok, as Jo says I don't think you can actually find the center of mass of the universe, but just for the sake of argument suppose you could. That still doesn't give you "absolute motion". All that gives you is motion relative to that point. You can do that with any point in the universe. And the point doesn't have to be tied to a planet, galaxy, or anything. It could just as easily be floating in space.
 
 Let me reiterate this point, because it's really key here. There is no such thing as absolute motion. Not even a little bit. All motion must be relative to a frame of reference, and all frames of reference are equally valid. You could pick absoluely any body in the universe, and I could define a frame of reference where that body isn't moving, and one where it's travelling at almost the speed of light, and both of those would be equally valid. Your body would really, actually be holding still relative to the first frame, and would really be travelling at almost the speed of light relative to the other frame.
 
 I think the reason you're having trouble here is that you've spent your whole life in the Earth's frame of reference. All the stuff sitting around you isn't moving relative to the Earth, and so it's really easy to believe that it isn't moving at all. And when things do move, they move relative to the earth. We know intellectually that the earth's frame of reference isn't absolute, but instinctively we treat it that way, unless we're doing astronomy or space flight. But it does get us used to wanting an absolute frame to measure everything against, even though no such thing exists.

 For this thought experiment, think of the universe as a baloon filled with water.
 Water is evenly distributed, so it is fairly homogenous.
 If the baloon is all of existence, then picking one of the molecules of the water swirling around inside as a reference point to map out the rest of the water molecules (stars, planets, and galaxys) would be kind of silly. The rest of the baloon would revolve around the single molecule that you picked.
 As time went on your reference point would change, and your map would go to ****, and nobody would buy it.
 If you could use the surface of the baloon as a reference point that would be ideal, it is the inside of the baloons absolute motion 0. Anywhere in the baloon could be referenced to the baloons surface to tell you the absolute motion of that mollecule of water (Planet, star, galaxy) within the universe.
 But seeing as how the universe does not have an outer membrane (at least that we know of), you would have to take the average motion of all matter and use that as your reference point. And Yes it would probably be a point in space that would seem to be buzzing past us at 600 km/s but you could take that reference anywhere you wanted once you knew what direction and velocity we were traveling with respect to the origional point that you found. Then you would have a sweet map and everyone would buy one. emoticon_xagree

No, it is still infinite whether it continues to expand or collapses back. The expansion and contraction refers to distances inside the universe. You may recall I previously mentioned that the big bang was the point at which internal distances are all zero, but the universe itself was still infinite. Consequently even if that arbitrary internal distance starts shrinking again, the universe will still be infinite. There can be magnitudes of infinity. The dirac delta function illustrates this to some extent.

The frame of reference for absolute motion (when i win the nobel prize and am crowned king of the universe for discovering it emoticon_cool ) would be the average velocity of every particle in the universe taking into account both magnitude and direction of the particles.
 Our galaxy may be traveling many thousands or even millions of m/s relative to this frame of reference, but there may be particles that are standing still relative to the absolute motions frame of reference.

 It's a function, or more accurately a distribution, which is infinite at t=0 and 0 for all t not equal to zero. I'm not sure how Jo meant it to be relevant.

You Said "inside the universe". If there is an inside, then there would be an outside, wouldnt there. If the dimensions still hadnt taken form, then what was there before empty space?
 What is the dirac delta function?
 I can understand if you guys are getting sick of this conversation.

 
 Nobody knows what is "outside" the universe. Inside and outside are pretty imprecise terms, but when you have a language designed to describe physical space then what can you do? Not only do we not know what is "outside", the nature of the universe, as far as we understand it, means that we cannot know.
 
 The dirac delta function is the second order derivative of the modulus function. Basically it is infinitely valued at x=0 and zero valued elsewhere - it is a great big, infinitely tall, infinitely thin spike. The key thing is that when integrated over symmetric limits, the area of this spike is 1; and it is possible to have numerical factors in front of the delta function so that it takes that value when integrated, though the spike is still infinitely tall and infinitely thin. This gives functions that are clearly of different sizes, yet are still infinite in height. This allows the concept of different magintudes of infinity. I mentioned it to demonstrate that different things can be infinite while one is still clearly larger than the other.

 What is the modulus function?

I mean you have have different sizes of infinity. I'll try a different example. There are an infinite number of positive integers, yes? There are also an infinite number of even positive integers, yes? But there are twice as many integers as their are positive integers. So you have two infinite quantities, one of which is larger than the other. The point here is that the universe can be larger at one point in time than at another, but it will still be infinite at both times (yes I know I'm implying an absolute time but that's not really a problem in this instance).
 
 The modulus function is the function which has y=x for x<0 and y=-x for x<0. It is roughly v-shaped, with two lines symmetric about the y-axis at 90 degrees to each other. If you differentiate this with respect to x you get the sign function, which is 1 for x<0 and -1 for x<0. Differentiate again and you get the dirac delta function.

 So does this mean that space is expanding at the speed of time? I've gone crosseyed again!!! emoticon_frazzled

The rate of expansion is only defined in terms of time, so you can't really talk about the speed of time. The expansion of the universe is parameterised by the scale factor, a(t), and da/d=a'(t). a'/a is the hubble parameter, which gives the rate of expansion (pretty much). Please keep asking questions as I have an exam on this next week so it's good revision. :p

The modulus function is the function which has y=x for x<0 and y=-x for x<0. It is roughly v-shaped, with two lines symmetric about the y-axis at 90 degrees to each other. If you differentiate this with respect to x you get the sign function, which is 1 for x<0 and -1 for x<0. Differentiate again and you get the dirac delta function.

 What is the modulus function used for?

Well, in general a lot of things use the modulus function, it's a fairly standard mathematical tool. You'll find it used in quantum mechanics, for example, where caclulating the probability of a particle being in a given range of positions is done by taking the integral of the square of the modulus of the wavefunction, with some extra factors. In the simple form I described, however, the main use I can think of is the one I have been talkng about, deriving the dirac delta function.

The rate of expansion is only defined in terms of time, so you can't really talk about the speed of time. The expansion of the universe is parameterised by the scale factor, a(t), and da/d=a'(t). a'/a is the hubble parameter, which gives the rate of expansion (pretty much). Please keep asking questions as I have an exam on this next week so it's good revision. :p

I mean you have have different sizes of infinity. I'll try a different example. There are an infinite number of positive integers, yes? There are also an infinite number of even positive integers, yes? But there are twice as many integers as their are positive integers. So you have two infinite quantities, one of which is larger than the other. 
 

 
 I realize that this is a total aside, but that isn't quite right. Infinity does come in various sizes, or as the mathematicans would put it, orders. However, the integers and the even integers are of the same order. There aren't more of one than the other.
 
 Two infinite sets are of the same order if you can make a one to one mapping between them, with nothing left over on either side. To map the integers to the even integers all you would need to do is multiply the integer by two, and you'll get a unique mapping to an even integer, so they're of the same order.
 
 If you feel like discussing this more, we should probably start a new thread, this one is bouncing around enough as it is. :)

The visible universe is limited by the speed of light and the age of the universe. The expansion I was talking about refers to the whole universe.

 
 The expansion of the universe is the limiting factor. The real volume of the universe is greater than the observed.

Yes, the whole universe if much greater than the observable universe, but it is the whole universe that has its expansion subject to the hubble parameter. The expansion of the observable universe is simply determined by the speed of light - the observable universe at present is those parts of the universe within 15 billion light years of us (approx).

Wrote this on time travel on another forum.....
 
 Causal paradoxes are not really paradoxes at all. When someone goes back in time, what they are really doing is going back to a state where the universe has the same arrangement of causality.
 
 Making it more simple:
 It is like a chemical reaction that starts with a molecule, and finishes with a different molecule. Now recreate exactly the reaction so that nothing at all looks different, including the starting molecule. Then in the middle of the process drop end product of the first reaction in. According to that end product molecule, it has just been dropped into a reaction that happened in the past. Nothing is different, however the reaction progresses and that end product is brought into a different future because he has be inserted into the flow of the reaction; perhaps a different byproduct was produced in the reaction.
 
 The universe is a continum of quantum states of all particles in the universe. But at the basic level elementary particles are indistinguishable; two electrons in the same state for example. 
 
 When a person goes back in time they are just moving to a state identical to their own, and can interact with it. You can kill your father or hang out with your twin. After that time would continue into a different future as causality continued. The problem is, that the universe's quantum state in always changing causally. Travelling into the future is no problem because as long as you approach the speed of light, you are allowing the universe to move through its states naturally while the pace of your own slows. However moving back in time requires you to recreate the quantum conditions in the universe exactly how it was in the past. I don't see anyway around that fact because I don't see time as a thing independent of the structure of the universe. There is no independent 'time'. More like spacetime, or space-energy-quantumstate-time.
